summary: Presented as originally released in 1939. Includes themes and character depictions which may be offensive and problematic to contemporary audiences. Epic Civil War drama focuses on the life of petulant Southern belle Scarlett O'Hara. Starting with her idyllic life on a sprawling plantation, the film traces her survival through the tragic history of the South during the Civil War and Reconstruction, and her tangled love affairs with Ashley Wilkes and Rhett Butler.

reviews.content: One of my favorites! Definitely watch this movie!  Read the book to.

This movie is Hollywood at its finest. It's been a favorite of mine for many years. At least since I first read the book. I wish I could go back in time and watch it for the first time over again. There's a reason why it's still a classic after all these years.

One of the oldest and greatest examples of peak cinema. The cinematography was not only evolutionary for the time but has been regarded as some of the best cinematography in cinema ever since its release. Vivian Leigh (Scarlett O'Hara) and Clark Gable (Rhett Butler) gave brilliant performances with Vivian winning the Oscar for best Actress in a leading role. Alongside Vivian, Hattie McDaniel (Mammy) won the Oscar for best supporting actress and in doing so became the first African American to be nominated for and win an Academy award. The film also won 6 other oscars, 5 of which were behind the camera awards (Best Directing, Best Writing/Screenplay, Best Cinematography/Colour, Best Art Direction and Best Film Editing) the 6th Oscar the film won was Best Picture. After watching the film it is clear that the film deserved every award they won.

An epic. Gone With the Wind is another technicolour achievement from the same director who brought us "The Wizard of Oz". It's a romantic tragedy which is set against the backdrop of the American Civil War and Reconstruction era, elevated by Max Steiner's score, some beautiful set design, landscape scenes and cinematography, a strong supporting cast, and a powerhouse lead performance from Vivian Leigh. Perhaps it's overly long with some scenes overstaying their welcome; that would be my main criticism.

A lot has been made of the depiction of the Antebellum South as well as that of slaves at that time in history. While there is merit to some of the criticism, I believe works of art should be judged as products of their time. Also, the film is based on a fictional romantic novel set against the backdrop of a real conflict, so I believe the creators are allowed to take some creative liberties with their work. The film isn't claiming to be historically accurate, and shouldn't be treated as such. For all its faults, it's a part of cinematic history, and should be preserved, not cancelled.

Running at 233 minutes, "Gone With the Wind" with all it's technical problems and casting issues is a long film that never once loses it's footing and undeniably holds the viewers attention from beginning until the closing credits! The film was being produced alongside "The Wizard of Oz" (also 1939) but unlike the latter, was assured to be a grand and acclaimed work in Hollywood almost from the beginning. "The Wizard of Oz" of course is also a timeless masterpiece but one that also didn't have the extraordinary budget and cast as "Gone With the Wind". Clark Gable plays the wealthy but rough and lively aristocrat Rhett Butler and the gorgeous Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara alongside an enormously gifted and delightful cast of character actors and other actors, all of which deliver impeccable performances here.
     The film begins before the Civil War during a lighthearted and decadent time of prosperity in the South, when the war finally breaks out destroying this tranquility. Over years of fighting and the defeat of the South, the O'Haras are left with nothing but the tattered remains of Tara (the families plantation). Scarlett must learn to grow up fast and becomes the head of the family and must pick up the pieces. Scarlett takes her life and that of her families into her hands and the fate of Tara resides solely with her will and sacrifices along the way.
     There are some very iconic quotes and mesmerizing scenes in the film and even 75 years later, they continue to astound and arrest viewers to this day. There are many scenes that demonstrate a tremendous visual scope and are still beautiful to watch, especially considering the little known three strip Technicolor that was being utilized with minimal testing. Some of the greatest and most poignant scenes include the burning of Atlanta, the street shots of the dead and injured Confederate soldiers which utilized a stunning crane shot (in a film that used very little camera movement), and the silhouette of Scarlett O'hara vow "As God as my witness, I'll never go hungry again". "Gone With the Wind" is a story of hope and redemption, what may appear to be the end and insurmountable is only at that particular moment, there's always tomorrow. "Gone With the Wind" went on to win 10 Academy Awards including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress (Vivien Leigh), and Best Supporting Actress (Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American to win an Oscar). It is also currently ranked #6 on The American Film Institute's Top 100 Films of All Time.

A well written and beautifully shot epic. The filmmaker took an admirable risk to tell a story about a beautiful, but very manipulative, selfish, and cutthroat Southern Belle. It's clear to all the characters, and the viewer, on how flawed Scarlett O'Hara is; but despite that, you can't help but fall in love with her and root for her. That's the beauty of great story telling; to make you sympathize and understand a character you wouldn't otherwise. To call it a masterpiece is an understatement. And by the way, Melanie is the purest angel I've ever seen in film. She reminds me of my wife.

An absolutely dazzling portrayal of civil war and reconstruction America in the South, Gone with the Wind also tells the story of an equally dramatic story about the human spirit, relationships and romantic intrigue. And also, it's very satisfying to hear that classic quote at the end.
Visually it's a masterpiece and the depiction of the American Civil War is genius.

The breathtaking majesty of "Gone with the Wind" cannot be denied, although we can and should recognize the morally problematic implications of its nostalgia for a society that profited from the abomination of slavery. The film certainly can't escape responsibility for such an indulgence, but the educated and enlightened mind can look upon it in a state of wonder regarding the universally relatable strengths which the film does possess. The timeless romance between Scarlet and Rhett has been pondered exhaustively, but the the enduring brilliance of the film derives from a scope which extends well beyond the parameters of their relationship. One might realize, for example, that the film offers a striking commentary on the nature and importance of resilience when life would seem at its most hopeless, as well as a blistering commentary on the thoughtless cruelty that we are capable of inflicting upon one another when in the moments of our deepest pain. In the end, we can't help but draw strength from Scarlet's stubborn and even selfish resilience, realizing in the process that even the seemingly weakest and most petty among us hold the keys to our own salvation. "Gone with the Wind" thus works not merely as an operatic ode to a troubling time that has receded into the pages of our history books, but also as an affirmation of what it means to consider tomorrow as another day.

The setting is a Georgia plantation. The year is 1861, and sixteen-year-old Scarlett O'Hara is infatuated with the blond, drowsy-eyed Ashley Wilkes - the problem is, Ashley plans to marry another woman. Little matter that every other man in the county is courting Scarlett and that a charming scoundrel named Rhett Butler is staring at her with questionable intent - she cares only for Ashley.

Suddenly, the Civil War brakes out, changing the fates and fortunes of all. Scarlett, clever, manipulative, and charming, proves an adept survivor - but what will she have to do to survive? And will she ever learn whom it is that she really loves?

GWTW is one of the most meticulously cast films ever; with the possible exception of Leslie Howard as Ashley (in his forties, rather old to be playing a man half that age), every role was perfectly assigned. After you watch Vivien Leigh you will be unable to imagine anyone else playing Scarlett, and Hattie McDaniel's strong, unforgettable performance as "Mammy" netted her an academy award (the first for an African-American actor).

GWTW's backdrop is the gruesome Civil War, and in the end this film is the story a woman and a civilization (the Old South) going through a war that will not leave either of them unchanged.

The cinematography is beautiful, memorable. Gone With the Wind was shot entirely in gorgeous technicolor; the scene of the fire in Atlanta required the use of all eight technicolor cameras in existence at the time.

The pragmatic may think Gone with the Wind overly dramatic; the restless may find it too long; the action-stimulated, too subtle. None of this, however, detracts from the fact that GWTW retains a lasting appeal as one of the crowning cinematic achievements of the 20th century. Those who see its ending as depressing - tragic, even - perhaps miss the point - which Scarlett O'Hara makes in her very last instant with us, tear-stained eyes uplifted in a sudden, curious burst of hope beneath all the turmoil; that .. . "After all, tomorrow is another day."

AFI 100 Greatest Films - #4: As technically well made as this epic adaptation of Margaret Mitchell's famous novel is, it is hard to rectify the historical inaccuracies and omissions if someone is viewing a film like this, for example, "to learn what times were like back during the Civil War" (the prospect of which is terrifying but unfortunately true still today). I think it is more important to watch a film like this to get an idea what it was like in 1930s America and how comfortable enough people were with elevating such a distorted view of history, even if understandably, as it provided a view which allowed many of these same people to keep from having to confront their families horrific pasts. This movie definitely drags on for me at around four hours yet the novel I remember being a surprisingly well flowing and quick read for it's length of over 1000 pages, likely a large reason for it's wide popularity.
On a side note this also reaffirms my decision to skip Birth of a Nation in my viewing of the AFI 100 list.

Gone with the Wind is a classic starring Clark Gable as Captain Rhett Butler and Vivian Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara, a tale of love and war. "Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn" is a famous line delivered by Clark Gable in this movie, as well as, "I can't think about that now, I'll think about that tomorrow," delivered by Vivian Leigh who plays the melodramatic Scarlett O'Hara. Then, there is the character, Ashley Wilkes.

It needs a good knowledge of the context in which the action of the film takes place to understand the script's symbolism. Certainly, a savvy spectator will discern between the Yankeedoom - Deep South political disputes, the "blackface" myths, and last but not least, about the justification of the Jim Crow laws that were in high esteem in the 4th decade of the last century. Beyond the appearance of a bucolic and innocent script, the film is a powerful manifesto of the lost cause that can fool an uninformed spectator, as in the sorcerer's apprentice's case. Still must be seen and explained to the young generation to understand the need to tackle racial problems and the power of propaganda.

For the 80th anniversary of Gone With the Wind, I'm going to analyze Scarlett O'Hara's character arc. Scarlett (Vivien Leigh) is a temperamental and vain Southern Belle from the Tara plantation who experiences the ups and downs in marriage, practices in medicine, deaths in the family, motherhood, and optimism. In spite of her courage and passion, she's spoiled and childish as she consumes riches and fashion and denies that the Civil War will occur. She reaches the first step of maturity when she witnesses the casualties of her father (Thomas Mitchell), her mother (Barbara O'Neill), Melanie (Olivia de Havilland), Charles Hamilton (Rand Brooks), her daughter Bonnie Blue (Cammie King Conlon), and thousands of Confederate soldiers. When Rhett Butler (Clark Gable) comes into the picture, she pushes him aside, seeing him as an interference to her social status. In reality, the weakness is her failure to wake up from her misguided romances and her insecurities. After the death of Melanie, she finally pulls the wall of her eyes and intervenes with Rhett, who leaves her and utters, "Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn." The majority of Scarlett's torment is stemmed from her constant death experiences, her fantastical expectations of romance, and her maturity progression. It was a long and difficult step for Scarlett to grow up, but in the end, the wind would have consumed her along with her family otherwise. Furthermore, Scarlett O'Hara shooting a Yankee in the face was friggin' awesome.

If there was ever a movie to call "perfect," 1939's "Gone with the Wind" would be it. First, let's address what everyone has addressed in recent times: its racial depictions. Personally, I take no offense to the racial depictions found within this film. It's not that I think they would fit well in society today, nor that I condone them, but I feel that it's unfair to hold a film made over eighty years ago to the same standards we hold films today. However, I can see why some people would take offense. These cultural depictions are outdated, and it's worth acknowledging that.

However, that is no reason to hate this amazing, beautiful, epic, and poetic film, nor is there reason to ignore the overwhelming merits and influence of this film. The acting is superb, the story captivating, the characters compelling, the visuals stunning – this film does everything perfectly. It really is a masterpiece. The best way to describe this film would be "poetry in motion"... this film feels like one long poem, and it's done perfectly. In my opinion, this is the greatest film ever made, and I absolutely love it.

Again, it is worth acknowledging the historical context of this film, and that some of its cultural depictions are outdated, but that should not preclude anybody from enjoying it, nor from acknowledging its merits. This film remains a cinematic golden standard, and I hope this film remains cherished for generations to come.
